questions.text: The structure shown (with black arrow) in the following image lies?

options.label: A
options.text: 1cm posterior to posterior end of inferior turbinate

options.label: B
options.text: 1cm posterior to posterior end of middle turbinate

options.label: C
options.text: 1cm posterior to anterior end of inferior turbinate

options.label: D
options.text: 1cm posterior to anterior end of middle turbinate

questions.correct_answer: A. 1cm posterior to posterior end of inferior turbinate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1cm posterior to posterior end of inferior turbinate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation of Options:
  • • Option A. 1cm posterior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate
  • • Option A. 1cm posterior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate
  • • This option correctly identifies the location of the Eustachian tube orifice. The Eustachian tube orifice is located in the nasopharynx, approximately 1 cm posterior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate.
  • • Option B. 1cm posterior to the posterior end of the middle turbinate
  • • Option B. 1cm posterior to the posterior end of the middle turbinate
  • • This option refers to the location of the sphenopalatine foramen, not the Eustachian tube orifice. The sphenopalatine foramen is situated posteriorly to the middle turbinate in the lateral nasal wall.
  • • Option C. 1cm posterior to the anterior end of the inferior turbinate
  • • Option C. 1cm posterior to the anterior end of the inferior turbinate
  • • This option relates to the opening of the nasolacrimal duct. The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus, which is located near the anterior end of the inferior turbinate.
  • • Option D. 1cm posterior to the anterior end of the middle turbinate
  • • Option D. 1cm posterior to the anterior end of the middle turbinate
  • • This option pertains to the bulla ethmoidalis, a prominent feature in the lateral nasal wall associated with the ethmoid sinus, not the Eustachian tube orifice.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Eustachian tube orifice is located approximately 1 cm posterior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate.

questions.text: A 45 - year - old man presents with a 3 - month history of intermittent, sharp pain in his right ear. He denies any hearing loss, tinnitus, or discharge. Physical examination of the ear is unremarkable. However, the patient reports a recent history of throat discomfort and difficulty swallowing. What is the most likely cause of his referred otalgia?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • A. Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorder: - TMJ disorder can cause referred pain to the ear due to its proximity to the ear canal. However, it typically presents with additional symptoms such as jaw pain, clicking, or locking, which are not reported by this patient.
  • • C. Vocal cord palsy: - Vocal cord palsy can cause throat discomfort and difficulty swallowing due to impaired vocal cord function. However, it is not typically associated with sharp, intermittent ear pain. Symptoms are more related to voice changes and aspiration issues.
  • • D. Cervical spine pathology: - Cervical spine issues can cause referred pain to the ear through nerve root irritation. However, they often present with neck pain or radiating pain to the shoulder and arm, which this patient does not report.

questions.text: A 60 - year - old male patient is admitted to the ICU and requires a tracheostomy due to prolonged mechanical ventilation. Which of the following is the most appropriate site for performing a tracheostomy?

options.label: A
options.text: At the level of the cricoid cartilage

options.label: B
options.text: Between the first and second tracheal rings

options.label: C
options.text: Between the second and third tracheal rings

questions.correct_answer: C. Between the second and third tracheal rings
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Between the second and third tracheal rings

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate site for a tracheostomy is between the second and third tracheal rings, as it minimizes the risk of complications and provides a stable location for the tracheostomy tube.

questions.text: A 62 - year - old male presents with a 3 - month history of hoarseness, mild dysphagia, and a persistent sore throat. He is a heavy smoker with a 40 - pack - year history. Laryngoscopy reveals a mass involving the entire right vocal cord with impaired mobility but no extension beyond the vocal cord. A CT scan of the neck shows no lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. What is the stage of this patient's laryngeal carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) T3N0M0

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngeal carcinoma involving the entire vocal cord with impaired mobility, without extension beyond the vocal cord or distant metastasis, is classified as T3N0M0.

questions.text: A 54 - year - old man with poorly controlled diabetes presents with a 2 - week history of facial pain, nasal congestion, and a black necrotic lesion on the palate. He also reports fever and worsening headache. Physical examination reveals facial swelling and a necrotic ulcer on the hard palate. MRI of the sinuses shows extensive sinusitis with bony destruction. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Broad - spectrum antibiotics and supportive care

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical debridement and intravenous amphotericin B

options.label: D
options.text: Oral antifungal therapy and nasal irrigation

questions.correct_answer: C. Surgical debridement and intravenous amphotericin B
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Surgical debridement and intravenous amphotericin B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial treatment for sinonasal mucormycosis involves aggressive surgical debridement and intravenous amphotericin B to address the invasive fungal infection and reduce mortality.

questions.text: A 35 - year - old woman presents with sudden onset of right - sided facial weakness. She is unable to close her right eye or raise the right side of her mouth. She denies any recent trauma, ear pain, or upper respiratory infection. On examination, there is complete right - sided facial paralysis, loss of the nasolabial fold, and inability to wrinkle her forehead on the affected side. There is no limb weakness or sensory deficit. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bell's palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bell's palsy presents as a sudden onset of unilateral peripheral facial paralysis involving both the upper and lower face, characterized by the inability to close the eye and wrinkle the forehead on the affected side.

questions.text: A 25 - year - old male presents to the clinic with a 3 - day history of fever, headache, and painful swelling in the region of the jaw and cheeks. He also complains of difficulty chewing and hearing loss in the right ear. On physical examination, there is significant swelling and tenderness of the right parotid gland. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum amylase levels. Which of the following complications was most likely developed in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sensorineural hearing loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sensorineural hearing loss is a rare but recognized complication of mumps, which can occur due to viral involvement of the cochlea or auditory nerve.

questions.text: A 30 - year - old woman presents with a 2 - day history of severe ear pain and decreased hearing in her right ear. She denies any recent upper respiratory infections, trauma, or water exposure. Otoscopic examination reveals the findings shown in the image. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mycoplasma pneumoniae

Explanation:

  • • Option A. Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • • Option A. Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • • Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of acute otitis media but is less commonly associated with myringitis bullosa, which is characterized by painful hemorrhagic bullae on the tympanic membrane as shown in the image.
  • • Option B. Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • • Option B. Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is typically associated with malignant otitis externa, particularly in diabetics. It does not commonly cause myringitis bullosa.
  • • Option C. Haemophilus influenzae
  • • Option C. Haemophilus influenzae
  • • Haemophilus influenzae is another common pathogen for acute otitis media but, like Streptococcus pneumoniae, is not the primary cause of myringitis bullosa.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myringitis bullosa is most commonly caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae and is characterized by painful hemorrhagic bullae on the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 45 - year - old man presents with a 3 - month history of hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in his right ear. He denies any pain, fever, or recent infections. On otoscopic examination, the tympanic membrane appears retracted with an air - fluid level visible behind it as shown in the image. There is no erythema or bulging of the tympanic membrane. Audiometry confirms conductive hearing loss in the right ear. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Referral for nasopharyngoscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In adults presenting with chronic serous otitis media, it is essential to perform nasopharyngoscopy to rule out nasopharyngeal carcinoma or other obstructive pathology before considering further management options such as tympanostomy tube placement.

questions.text: A 42 - year - old woman presents with a history of asthma, recurrent nasal polyps, and episodes of wheezing and shortness of breath following the use of aspirin. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of her condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Cyclooxygenase - 1 (cox - 1) inhibition leading to leukotriene overproduction

questions.correct_answer: B. Cyclooxygenase - 1 (cox - 1) inhibition leading to leukotriene overproduction
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) inhibition leading to leukotriene overproduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Samter's triad involves a combination of asthma, nasal polyps, and aspirin sensitivity due to the inhibition of COX - 1, leading to overproduction of leukotrienes and resulting in bronchoconstriction and inflammation.
  • ➤ -

questions.text: A 28 - year - old woman presents with a sudden onset of hearing loss in her right ear. She reports no pain, trauma, or previous ear problems. Audiometry reveals sensorineural hearing loss. An MRI is ordered to evaluate the inner ear structures. Which of the following structures is primarily responsible for converting sound waves into neural signals?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Basilar membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The basilar membrane within the cochlea is primarily responsible for converting sound waves into neural signals by supporting the organ of Corti, where hair cells transduce mechanical vibrations into electrical impulses.

questions.text: A 17 - year - old male presents with recurrent episodes of severe nasal bleeding over the past six months. He also complains of nasal obstruction and occasional headaches. On physical examination, there is a mass visible in the nasopharynx. Imaging studies reveal a highly vascular mass centered in the posterior nasal cavity extending into the nasopharynx with bony destruction. What is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Endoscopic surgical resection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial step in the management of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is endoscopic surgical resection to directly remove the highly vascular tumor and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: A 35 - year - old woman presents with progressive dyspnea and stridor over the past six months. She has no significant past medical history and denies any recent respiratory infections or trauma. Laryngoscopy reveals narrowing of the subglottic airway. What is the most likely underlying cause of her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subglottic stenosis in a patient without a history of intubation or trauma should raise suspicion for autoimmune conditions such as Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis), which can cause chronic inflammation and narrowing of the subglottic airway.

questions.text: A 60 - year - old male presents with a 3 - month history of hoarseness, difficulty swallowing, and occasional aspiration of liquids. He has a 40 - pack - year smoking history and reports recent unintentional weight loss. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals left vocal cord paralysis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?

options.label: A
options.text: Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury from thyroid surgery

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bronchogenic carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with vocal cord paralysis and a significant smoking history, bronchogenic carcinoma should be considered as the most likely underlying cause due to its potential to compress the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A 40 - year - old woman presents with a long - standing history of nasal congestion, crusting, and a foul odor emanating from her nose. She also reports frequent nosebleeds and a loss of sense of smell. On examination, there is extensive crusting and atrophy of the nasal mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely etiological factor for her condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Long - term use of topical nasal decongestants

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Klebsiella ozaenae infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis, characterized by nasal crusting, atrophy of the nasal mucosa, and foul odor, is often caused by a chronic infection with Klebsiella ozaenae.

questions.text: A 55 - year - old male with a history of hypertension presents with recurrent episodes of severe nosebleeds that have not responded to anterior nasal packing. He has been treated multiple times in the emergency department for these episodes, and each time the bleeding recurs shortly after discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.correct_answer: A. Ligation of the sphenopalatine artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ligation of the sphenopalatine artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intractable epistaxis that does not respond to conventional measures, such as anterior nasal packing, may require surgical intervention, such as ligation of the sphenopalatine artery, to effectively control the bleeding.

questions.text: A 10 - year - old boy undergoes a tonsillectomy for recurrent tonsillitis. Six hours postoperatively, he develops significant bleeding from the surgical site. What is the most appropriate initial management for this complication?

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate return to the operating room for hemostasis

questions.correct_answer: C. Immediate return to the operating room for hemostasis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Immediate return to the operating room for hemostasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Significant postoperative hemorrhage following a tonsillectomy requires immediate surgical intervention to achieve hemostasis and prevent severe blood loss and complications.

questions.text: A 32 - year - old woman with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) presents with severe headache, fever, and otorrhea. She also reports nausea, vomiting, and a recent onset of diplopia. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the mastoid area and papilledema. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Empiric intravenous antibiotics and supportive care

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate MRI or MRV of the brain

options.label: D
options.text: Lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis

questions.correct_answer: C. Immediate MRI or MRV of the brain
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Immediate MRI or MRV of the brain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with chronic suppurative otitis media presenting with severe headache, fever, and neurological symptoms, immediate imaging with MRI or MRV is essential to diagnose potential intracranial complications such as sigmoid sinus thrombosis.

questions.text: A 40 - year - old man with a history of chronic otitis media presents with hearing loss and intermittent ear discharge. Otoscopic examination reveals a large central perforation of the tympanic membrane. Audiometry shows conductive hearing loss. He is scheduled for tympanoplasty. What is the primary goal of tympanoplasty in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Improve cosmetic appearance of the tympanic membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Restore continuity of the ossicular chain

options.label: C
options.text: Reconstruct the tympanic membrane and eradicate middle ear disease

options.label: D
options.text: Prevent future episodes of acute otitis media

questions.correct_answer: C. Reconstruct the tympanic membrane and eradicate middle ear disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reconstruct the tympanic membrane and eradicate middle ear disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary goal of tympanoplasty is to reconstruct the tympanic membrane and eradicate middle ear disease to improve hearing and prevent chronic ear infections.

questions.text: A 55 - year - old male presents with a laceration on the anterior surface of his right pinna following a minor trauma. He reports localized pain and mild bleeding. Which of the following nerves is primarily responsible for the sensory innervation of the anterior surface of the pinna?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Auriculotemporal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), provides sensory innervation to the anterior surface of the pinna.

questions.text: A 30 - year - old male presents with a 3 - month history of persistent ear discharge, hearing loss, and mild pain in his left ear. He has been treated multiple times with antibiotics without improvement. Otoscopic examination reveals a pale, thickened tympanic membrane with multiple perforations and granulation tissue. There is no history of trauma. His medical history includes close contact with a family member diagnosed with tuberculosis. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: High - resolution CT scan of the temporal bone

options.label: B
options.text: Empiric treatment with broad - spectrum antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Acid - fast bacilli (AFB) culture and biopsy of the granulation tissue

questions.correct_answer: C. Acid - fast bacilli (AFB) culture and biopsy of the granulation tissue
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acid-fast bacilli (AFB) culture and biopsy of the granulation tissue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with chronic otitis media unresponsive to standard antibiotic therapy and a history suggestive of tuberculosis, it is essential to perform an AFB culture and biopsy of the granulation tissue to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A 35 - year - old male presents to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. He is conscious and oriented but complains of severe headache and dizziness. On physical examination, there is bruising over the mastoid region behind his left ear, and periorbital ecchymosis is noted bilaterally. What is the most likely underlying injury associated with this physical finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Basilar skull fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Battle sign (bruising over the mastoid region) is an indication of a basilar skull fracture, which often presents with additional findings such as raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymosis), cerebrospinal fluid leakage, and hemotympanum.

questions.text: A 45 - year - old woman presents with chronic nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and sneezing. She reports that these symptoms are exacerbated by changes in temperature, strong odors, and emotional stress. She denies any itching, eye symptoms, or seasonal variation in her symptoms. Physical examination reveals boggy nasal mucosa without any polyps or significant discharge. Allergy testing is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vasomotor rhinitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vasomotor rhinitis is characterized by chronic nasal congestion and rhinorrhea triggered by non - allergic stimuli such as changes in temperature, strong odors, and emotional stress, with no associated itching or positive allergy tests.
  • ➤ -

questions.text: A 32 - year - old man presents to the emergency department after being struck in the face with a baseball. He complains of severe pain around his left eye, double vision, and difficulty moving his eye upward. On physical examination, there is significant periorbital swelling and bruising. To further evaluate his condition, a Water's view radiograph is obtained. Which of the following structures is best visualized with this imaging technique?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Maxillary sinus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Water's view (occipitomental view) radiograph is primarily used to visualize the maxillary sinuses and is helpful in assessing maxillary sinus pathology and orbital floor fractures.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a painless, slowly enlarging mass in her right parotid gland. She has no facial nerve weakness or other symptoms. On physical examination, there is a firm, mobile mass in the region of the parotid gland. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy is performed and the results suggest a pleomorphic adenoma. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Surgical excision

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The management of pleomorphic adenoma, a benign salivary gland tumor, involves surgical excision to prevent recurrence and potential malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 25 - year - old woman presents to the emergency department with a severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and fever for the past three days. She also reports muffled voice and trismus. On physical examination, there is asymmetrical swelling of the soft palate with deviation of the uvula to the right. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Oral antibiotics and outpatient follow - up

options.label: C
options.text: Needle aspiration or incision and drainage of the abscess

questions.correct_answer: C. Needle aspiration or incision and drainage of the abscess
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Needle aspiration or incision and drainage of the abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial management of a peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) involves needle aspiration or incision and drainage of the abscess, followed by antibiotic therapy to effectively treat the infection and prevent complications.

questions.text: A 6 - year - old child is diagnosed with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL). Which of the following management options is least likely to be preferred for this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Making him sit in the front row in class

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is not preferred for managing bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in a child, as it is more suited for treating middle ear conditions rather than sensorineural hearing issues.

questions.text: A 55 - year - old male presents with dysphagia and hoarseness of voice. An MRI scan reveals a mass compressing the structures passing through the gap between the inferior constrictor muscle and the esophagus. Which of the following structures is most likely affected?

options.label: B
options.text: Internal laryngeal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Recurrent laryngeal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recurrent laryngeal nerve passes between the inferior constrictor muscle and the esophagus, and compression of this nerve in this region can lead to dysphagia and hoarseness of voice.

questions.text: A 6 - year - old child presents with bilateral hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in the ears following a recent upper respiratory infection. The child is diagnosed with otitis media with effusion (OME). Which of the following statements about otitis media with effusion is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: It undergoes spontaneous resolution after the cold decreases

options.label: D
options.text: It shows Ad type of tympanogram

questions.correct_answer: D. It shows Ad type of tympanogram
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It shows Ad type of tympanogram

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otitis media with effusion typically shows a type B tympanogram, indicating fluid in the middle ear, and is often associated with upper respiratory infections, frequently resolving spontaneously after the cold decreases.

questions.text: A 12 - year - old girl presents with chronic nasal congestion, sneezing, and itchy, watery eyes, particularly during the pollen season. On physical examination, she has dark circles under her eyes and a transverse nasal crease. Which of the following findings is not commonly associated with allergic rhinitis?

options.label: D
options.text: Extra folds below the lower eyelids

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Horizontal forehead lines

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Horizontal forehead lines (Otto Veraguth folds) are not typically seen in allergic rhinitis, whereas dark circles under the eyes, a transverse nasal crease, and Dennie - Morgan lines are common findings.
  • ➤ -

questions.text: A 45 - year - old woman presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in her right ear. Each episode lasts several hours and is associated with nausea and vomiting. What is the most likely underlying pathology in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Meniere's disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meniere's disease is characterized by recurrent episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, differentiating it from other causes of vertigo such as BPPV, vestibular neuritis, and acoustic neuroma.

questions.text: A 30 - year - old man from a rural area in South India presents with a history of progressive nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and a mass protruding from his left nostril. He reports no history of trauma or recent infections. On examination, there is a red, friable polypoid mass in the nasal cavity that bleeds easily on touch. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients from endemic areas presenting with a red, friable, polypoid nasal mass that bleeds easily on touch.

questions.text: A 28 - year - old woman presents with progressive hearing loss and tinnitus. Audiometric testing reveals high - frequency hearing loss. A detailed study of her cochlear hair cells is performed. Which of the following statements best describes a key difference between inner and outer hair cells in the cochlea?

options.label: A
options.text: Inner hair cells amplify sound vibrations, while outer hair cells primarily send auditory signals to the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: Inner hair cells are fewer in number and primarily send auditory signals to the brain, while outer hair cells amplify sound vibrations.

options.label: C
options.text: Outer hair cells are fewer in number and primarily send auditory signals to the brain, while inner hair cells amplify sound vibrations.

options.label: D
options.text: Outer hair cells are responsible for detecting sound direction, while inner hair cells amplify sound vibrations.

questions.correct_answer: B. Inner hair cells are fewer in number and primarily send auditory signals to the brain, while outer hair cells amplify sound vibrations.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Inner hair cells are fewer in number and primarily send auditory signals to the brain, while outer hair cells amplify sound vibrations.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inner hair cells are fewer in number and primarily send auditory signals to the brain, while outer hair cells are more numerous and play a crucial role in amplifying sound vibrations within the cochlea.

questions.text: A 10 - year - old boy presents with a history of fluctuating hearing loss and difficulty understanding speech, especially in noisy environments. Despite normal otoacoustic emissions, his auditory brainstem response (ABR) is absent. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss due to cochlear damage

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Auditory neuropathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Auditory neuropathy is characterized by normal otoacoustic emissions and absent or abnormal auditory brainstem responses (ABR), indicating a disruption in the transmission of sound from the inner ear to the brain despite normal cochlear function.

questions.text: A 3 - month - old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic for a follow - up after a failed newborn hearing screening. The initial screening was performed using otoacoustic emissions (OAE) testing. Which of the following best explains the purpose and significance of otoacoustic emissions in newborn hearing screening?

options.label: A
options.text: OAE testing measures the function of the auditory nerve and brainstem pathways

options.label: B
options.text: OAE testing can detect conductive hearing loss by measuring middle ear pressure

options.label: C
options.text: OAE testing assesses the function of outer hair cells in the cochlea

options.label: D
options.text: OAE testing evaluates the overall hearing ability by measuring behavioral responses to sound

questions.correct_answer: C. OAE testing assesses the function of outer hair cells in the cochlea
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) OAE testing assesses the function of outer hair cells in the cochlea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) testing assesses the function of the outer hair cells in the cochlea and is used in newborn hearing screening to detect potential cochlear dysfunction.

questions.text: A 45 - year - old man presents with a long - standing history of recurrent otitis media and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals a retracted tympanic membrane with visible bony structures. The patient is evaluated using the Sade grading system for pars tensa retraction. What does a Grade 2 retraction indicate in this system?

options.label: A
options.text: Retraction of the tympanic membrane with contact to the incus or stapes

options.label: B
options.text: Retraction pocket involving only the pars flaccida

options.label: C
options.text: Retraction of the tympanic membrane onto the promontory

options.label: D
options.text: Retraction of the tympanic membrane with prominent handle of malleus

questions.correct_answer: A. Retraction of the tympanic membrane with contact to the incus or stapes
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Retraction of the tympanic membrane with contact to the incus or stapes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the Sade grading system for pars tensa retraction, a Grade 2 retraction indicates that the tympanic membrane is retracted and in contact with the incus or stapes.

questions.text: Where do the structures marked "EB" drain?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Middle meatus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ethmoid bulla (EB) drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 35 - year - old man presents with a history of hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in his right ear. Tympanometry is performed as part of impedance audiometry. The results show a type B tympanogram. Which of the following conditions is most consistent with this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Middle ear effusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A type B tympanogram, characterized by a flat tracing with no peak, is most consistent with the presence of a middle ear effusion.

questions.text: A 45 - year - old woman presents with progressive hearing loss in both ears. She has no history of noise exposure, ototoxic medication use, or ear infections. Pure tone audiometry reveals a bilateral sloping high - frequency hearing loss. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Presbycusis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Presbycusis is characterized by a bilateral sloping high - frequency hearing loss seen on pure tone audiometry, common in older adults as part of the natural aging process.
  • ➤ -

questions.text: A patient presents with a hearing disorder, and you are evaluating the auditory pathway to determine the site of lesion. Arrange the following structures in the correct sequence of the auditory pathway from the periphery to the cortex: 1. Cochlear nucleus 2. Spiral ganglion 3. Superior olivary nucleus 4. Inferior colliculus 5. Medial geniculate body
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2-1-3-4-5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of the auditory pathway from the periphery to the cortex is: Spiral ganglion - > Cochlear nucleus - > Superior olivary nucleus - > Inferior colliculus - > Medial geniculate body.
  • ➤ -
  • ➤ -
  • ➤ -
  • ➤ -

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of laryngeal carcinoma underwent a total laryngectomy and now uses a tracheo-esophageal prosthesis (TEP) for voice rehabilitation. He presents to the clinic with dysphagia, frequent coughing during meals, and difficulty speaking through the prosthesis. On examination, there is no evidence of infection or significant edema around the prosthesis site. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Fistula formation around the tracheo-esophageal prosthesis

options.label: D
options.text: Granulation tissue formation around the prosthesis

questions.correct_answer: A. Fistula formation around the tracheo-esophageal prosthesis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fistula formation around the tracheo-esophageal prosthesis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Fistula formation around the tracheo-esophageal prosthesis - This is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms. Fistula formation can result in leakage of saliva and food into the trachea, causing dysphagia, coughing during meals, and difficulty speaking. The absence of infection or significant edema does not rule out a fistula, which is a known complication of TEP.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Prosthesis displacement - While displacement can cause issues with speech and possibly swallowing, it would likely be identified on physical examination. The absence of visible displacement makes this less likely in this scenario.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Candida infection of the prosthesis - Candida infection can cause prosthesis dysfunction and discomfort but is usually associated with visible signs of infection, such as redness, discharge, or edema. The absence of these signs makes this diagnosis less likely.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Granulation tissue formation around the prosthesis - Granulation tissue can lead to partial obstruction and difficulty speaking, but it typically presents with visible overgrowth at the prosthesis site, which would be noted on examination. The patient’s symptoms of dysphagia and coughing are more indicative of a fistula.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fistula formation around a tracheo-esophageal prosthesis can lead to dysphagia, coughing during meals, and difficulty speaking, making it a likely complication in patients presenting with these symptoms post-laryngectomy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with recurrent nasal obstruction and chronic sinusitis. Imaging reveals significant opacification in the anterior ethmoidal air cells, particularly the agger nasi cell. Which of the following structures is most likely to be directly affected by inflammation in the agger nasi cell?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Frontal recess

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Sphenoid sinus - The sphenoid sinus is located posteriorly and is not directly affected by the agger nasi cell, which is an anterior ethmoidal air cell.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Frontal recess - The agger nasi cell is the most anterior ethmoidal air cell and is located near the frontal recess. Inflammation or infection in the agger nasi cell can easily spread to the frontal recess, potentially leading to obstruction and contributing to frontal sinusitis.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Maxillary sinus - While the maxillary sinus is located near the ethmoidal air cells, it is primarily affected by the ostiomeatal complex. The agger nasi cell specifically affects the frontal recess more directly.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Nasolacrimal duct - The nasolacrimal duct drains the lacrimal sac into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity. It is not directly affected by the agger nasi cell.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inflammation or infection in the agger nasi cell can directly affect the frontal recess, potentially leading to obstruction and frontal sinusitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a history of chronic facial pain, pressure sensation below the eyes, and recurrent episodes of sinusitis. CT imaging of the paranasal sinuses reveals an infraorbital ethmoidal air cell. Which of the following complications is most likely associated with this anatomical variant known as a Haller cell?

options.label: C
options.text: Obstruction of the maxillary sinus ostium

questions.correct_answer: C. Obstruction of the maxillary sinus ostium
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Obstruction of the maxillary sinus ostium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Orbital cellulitis - While Haller cells can be located near the orbit, they primarily affect the drainage pathways of the paranasal sinuses rather than directly causing orbital infections. Orbital cellulitis is usually a complication of ethmoid or maxillary sinusitis, not specifically linked to Haller cells.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Frontal sinusitis - Haller cells are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells and do not typically affect the frontal sinus. Their anatomical location makes them more relevant to the maxillary sinus and its drainage.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Obstruction of the maxillary sinus ostium - Haller cells are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells that can impinge on the maxillary sinus ostium, leading to obstruction. This can result in recurrent maxillary sinusitis and symptoms such as facial pain and pressure below the eyes.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Sphenoid sinusitis - The sphenoid sinus is located posteriorly and is not directly affected by Haller cells, which are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells. Haller cells primarily influence the drainage of the maxillary sinus.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Haller cells, which are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells, can obstruct the maxillary sinus ostium, leading to recurrent maxillary sinusitis and related symptoms.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with episodes of vertigo triggered by changes in head position, such as turning in bed or looking up. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver reproduces her symptoms and reveals a characteristic upbeat and torsional nystagmus. You decide to perform the Epley maneuver. Which of the following statements about the Epley maneuver is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The Epley maneuver is effective for treating vertigo caused by Meniere’s disease.

options.label: B
options.text: The Epley maneuver repositions otoconia from the semicircular canal to the utricle.

options.label: C
options.text: The Epley maneuver involves rapid head movements to dislodge otoconia.

options.label: D
options.text: The Epley maneuver is contraindicated in patients with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

questions.correct_answer: B. The Epley maneuver repositions otoconia from the semicircular canal to the utricle.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The Epley maneuver repositions otoconia from the semicircular canal to the utricle.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The Epley maneuver is effective for treating vertigo caused by Meniere’s disease. - This is incorrect. The Epley maneuver is specifically designed to treat BPPV, not Meniere’s disease, which is a different inner ear disorder characterized by episodic vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. The Epley maneuver repositions otoconia from the semicircular canal to the utricle. - This is correct. BPPV is caused by dislodged otoconia (calcium carbonate crystals) that move into the semicircular canals. The Epley maneuver uses a series of head movements to guide these otoconia back into the utricle where they can no longer cause vertigo.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. The Epley maneuver involves rapid head movements to dislodge otoconia. - This is incorrect. The Epley maneuver involves a series of specific, controlled head and body movements, not rapid movements. The goal is to reposition, not dislodge, the otoconia.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. The Epley maneuver is contraindicated in patients with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). - This is incorrect. The Epley maneuver is the primary treatment for BPPV, designed to relieve symptoms by repositioning the otoconia.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Epley maneuver is used to treat benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) by repositioning otoconia from the semicircular canal to the utricle.

questions.text: A senior medical professional at the hospital is conducting the clinical examination depicted in the provided image. Which of the subsequent anatomical structures will not be visible to him?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adenoids

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Adenoids - Adenoids are lymphoid tissue located in the nasopharynx. They are not visible during a typical oral examination as shown in the image because they are situated above the soft palate and cannot be seen through the mouth.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Arytenoids - The arytenoids are cartilages located at the back of the larynx and can be visualized during an indirect laryngoscopy, which seems to be the procedure depicted in the image. They are visible along with the vocal cords.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Vocal cords - The vocal cords are located within the larynx and can be visualized during an indirect laryngoscopy using a mirror, as shown in the image. This is a standard procedure to examine the laryngeal structures.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Epiglottis - The epiglottis is a flap of cartilage located at the entrance of the larynx, which can also be seen during an indirect laryngoscopy. It plays a crucial role in directing food and air appropriately.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenoids, located in the nasopharynx, are not visible during an oral examination or indirect laryngoscopy as they are situated above the soft palate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male boxer presents to the emergency department with swelling, pain, and bruising over his right ear after a recent match. Physical examination reveals a fluctuant, tender mass on the anterior aspect of the pinna. He is diagnosed with a pinna hematoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management to prevent complications?

options.label: C
options.text: Incision and drainage with compression dressing

questions.correct_answer: C. Incision and drainage with compression dressing
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Incision and drainage with compression dressing

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Needle aspiration and compression dressing - While needle aspiration can temporarily alleviate the hematoma, it is often insufficient in preventing recurrence and complications. The blood can reaccumulate, necessitating a more definitive treatment such as incision and drainage.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Oral antibiotics and observation - Although oral antibiotics may be necessary if there is an infection, observation alone is not sufficient. Without proper drainage, the hematoma can lead to cartilage necrosis and deformity, known as "cauliflower ear."
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Incision and drainage with compression dressing - This is the correct and most effective initial management. Incision and drainage remove the accumulated blood, and the compression dressing prevents reaccumulation, reducing the risk of complications like infection and cartilage necrosis.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Corticosteroid injection into the hematoma - Corticosteroid injections are not appropriate for treating pinna hematomas and do not address the underlying issue of blood accumulation. They do not prevent complications such as cartilage necrosis or infection.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial management of a pinna hematoma involves incision and drainage with a compression dressing to prevent reaccumulation of blood, cartilage necrosis, and deformity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with recurrent episodes of epistaxis. On examination, the bleeding is localized to the anterior part of the nasal septum. The patient is diagnosed with a bleed originating from Kiesselbach's plexus. Which of the following arteries is NOT a component of Kiesselbach's plexus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Posterior ethmoidal artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Anterior ethmoidal artery - The anterior ethmoidal artery, a branch of the ophthalmic artery, contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus and supplies the anterior part of the nasal septum.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Greater palatine artery - The greater palatine artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, ascends into the nasal cavity and contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Sphenopalatine artery - The sphenopalatine artery, also a branch of the maxillary artery, is a major contributor to the nasal septum and Kiesselbach's plexus.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Posterior ethmoidal artery - The posterior ethmoidal artery, also a branch of the ophthalmic artery, primarily supplies the posterior part of the nasal cavity and the ethmoid sinuses. It does not significantly contribute to Kiesselbach's plexus, which is located in the anterior nasal septum.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior ethmoidal artery is not a component of Kiesselbach's plexus, which consists of the anterior ethmoidal artery, greater palatine artery, sphenopalatine artery, and the superior labial artery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with chronic sinusitis, and her physician orders a Caldwell view X-ray. Which of the following sinuses is best visualized with this imaging technique?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Frontal sinus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Sphenoid sinus - The sphenoid sinus is located deeper within the skull and is not best visualized using the Caldwell view. Instead, the lateral view or specialized sphenoid sinus views are better for this purpose.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Frontal sinus - The Caldwell view, also known as the occipitofrontal view, is particularly useful for visualizing the frontal sinus. This projection allows for a clear view of the frontal sinus anatomy and any pathological conditions affecting it.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Ethmoid sinus - While the ethmoid sinuses can be partially visualized in the Caldwell view, this view is not specifically optimized for them. CT scans are generally better for detailed imaging of the ethmoid sinuses.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Maxillary sinus - The maxillary sinus is best visualized with the Waters view (occipitomental view) rather than the Caldwell view.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Caldwell view (occipitofrontal view) is primarily used to visualize the frontal sinus in cases of sinusitis or other frontal sinus pathologies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with fever, severe pain behind the right ear, and swelling in the neck. He has a history of chronic otitis media. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the mastoid process and fluctuance in the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. CT scan shows a deep neck abscess extending from the mastoid process. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bezold abscess

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Bezold abscess - Bezold abscess is a deep neck abscess that extends from the mastoid process, often a complication of chronic mastoiditis. It spreads along the sternocleidomastoid muscle, which matches the presentation of pain, swelling in the neck, and a history of chronic otitis media.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Lemierre syndrome - Lemierre syndrome is characterized by septic thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein, typically following oropharyngeal infections. It presents with fever, neck pain, and septic emboli, but not with mastoid tenderness or extension along the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Gradenigo syndrome - Gradenigo syndrome involves petrous apicitis, presenting with a triad of otitis media, facial pain due to trigeminal nerve involvement, and abducens nerve palsy. It does not typically present with neck swelling or fluctuance.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Retropharyngeal abscess - Retropharyngeal abscess presents with symptoms such as fever, neck stiffness, dysphagia, and a bulging pharyngeal wall on examination. It is usually located in the retropharyngeal space, not extending from the mastoid process along the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bezold abscess is a deep neck abscess that extends from the mastoid process along the sternocleidomastoid muscle, often resulting from chronic mastoiditis.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up. The parents are concerned about the child's hearing, as the infant does not seem to respond consistently to auditory stimuli. The pediatrician decides to perform a Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) test. Which of the following conditions can be most accurately diagnosed using BERA?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Auditory neuropathy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Conductive hearing loss - Conductive hearing loss is typically due to issues in the outer or middle ear, such as earwax impaction or otitis media. While BERA can indicate abnormal hearing thresholds, it is not the best test for distinguishing conductive hearing loss, which is better assessed with otoscopic examination and tympanometry.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Auditory neuropathy - BERA is specifically useful for diagnosing auditory neuropathy, a condition where the transmission of sound from the inner ear to the brain is impaired despite normal outer hair cell function. BERA can detect the characteristic delayed or absent waveforms associated with this condition, making it the most accurate diagnostic tool in this context.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Central auditory processing disorder - Central auditory processing disorder (CAPD) involves difficulties in the processing of auditory information in the brain, rather than the detection of sound. BERA tests the auditory nerve and brainstem function and is not designed to diagnose CAPD, which requires behavioral and neuropsychological testing.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Noise-induced hearing loss - Noise-induced hearing loss primarily affects the hair cells in the cochlea and is usually detected by pure-tone audiometry. BERA can indicate hearing loss but does not specifically diagnose the type caused by noise exposure, which is better assessed with audiometric tests.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is most accurately used to diagnose auditory neuropathy by detecting abnormalities in the transmission of sound from the inner ear to the brainstem.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with chronic nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and snoring. His parents report frequent ear infections and a nasal quality to his speech. On physical examination, he has a "pinched" nose appearance and high arched palate. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient with adenoid hypertrophy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Conductive hearing loss

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Enlarged cervical lymph nodes - Enlarged cervical lymph nodes can be associated with various infections and inflammatory conditions but are not specifically indicative of adenoid hypertrophy.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Normal tympanic membrane mobility - In the presence of adenoid hypertrophy, tympanic membrane mobility is often decreased due to eustachian tube dysfunction leading to middle ear effusion. Therefore, normal tympanic membrane mobility is not a typical finding.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Enlarged lingual tonsils - While enlarged lingual tonsils can coexist with adenoid hypertrophy, they are not a direct consequence or the most likely additional finding in this condition. Adenoid hypertrophy primarily affects the nasopharynx and its adjacent structures.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Conductive hearing loss - Conductive hearing loss is a common consequence of adenoid hypertrophy due to eustachian tube dysfunction and resultant middle ear effusion. This condition can lead to decreased mobility of the tympanic membrane and impaired sound conduction.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenoid hypertrophy often leads to conductive hearing loss due to eustachian tube dysfunction and resultant middle ear effusion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and occasional dizziness. MRI of the brain reveals a mass at the cerebellopontine angle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acoustic neuroma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Meniere's disease - Meniere's disease typically presents with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, but it does not usually show a mass on MRI. It is a disorder of the inner ear rather than a mass at the cerebellopontine angle.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Acoustic neuroma - Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, is a benign tumor that arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII). It commonly presents with unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes balance disturbances. MRI findings of a mass at the cerebellopontine angle are characteristic of this condition.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Labyrinthitis - Labyrinthitis is an inflammation of the inner ear that typically presents with acute onset of vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus. It does not present as a mass on MRI.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Otosclerosis - Otosclerosis involves abnormal bone remodeling in the middle ear that leads to conductive hearing loss. It does not present as a mass on MRI and is not associated with the cerebellopontine angle.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acoustic neuroma, a benign tumor at the cerebellopontine angle, commonly presents with unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and occasional dizziness, and is diagnosed through MRI revealing a characteristic mass.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with chronic nasal congestion, nasal polyps, and a history of asthma. CT scan of the sinuses reveals characteristic findings of sinusitis with high-density mucus. Nasal discharge shows eosinophilic mucin without tissue invasion. Based on the provided criteria, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Chronic bacterial sinusitis - Chronic bacterial sinusitis typically presents with purulent nasal discharge, facial pain, and prolonged symptoms, but it does not include eosinophilic mucin or the characteristic CT findings associated with AFRS.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS) - AFRS is characterized by type I hypersensitivity, nasal polyposis, characteristic CT findings, eosinophilic mucin without invasion, and positive fungal stain. The patient's history of asthma and CT findings along with eosinophilic mucin fit the major criteria for AFRS.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Acute viral rhinosinusitis - Acute viral rhinosinusitis usually presents with symptoms lasting less than 10 days and does not involve chronic symptoms, nasal polyposis, or the specific CT findings seen in AFRS.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Non-allergic rhinitis - Non-allergic rhinitis involves chronic nasal symptoms without the involvement of type I hypersensitivity, eosinophilic mucin, or nasal polyposis seen in AFRS.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS) is diagnosed based on criteria including type I hypersensitivity, nasal polyposis, characteristic CT findings, eosinophilic mucin without invasion, and positive fungal stain.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with congenital bilateral conductive hearing loss has not benefited from traditional hearing aids due to chronic ear infections. The otolaryngologist recommends a bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA). Which of the following is a primary advantage of a bone-anchored hearing aid over traditional hearing aids?

options.label: C
options.text: Direct bone conduction bypassing the middle ear

questions.correct_answer: C. Direct bone conduction bypassing the middle ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Direct bone conduction bypassing the middle ear

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Enhanced sound localization - While BAHA devices can improve sound localization compared to unaided hearing, this is not their primary advantage over traditional hearing aids. Sound localization improvement depends more on binaural fitting and the individual's ability to adapt.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Improved aesthetic appearance - The aesthetic appearance of BAHA devices is not necessarily better than traditional hearing aids. The primary advantage lies in their functional performance for specific types of hearing loss.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Direct bone conduction bypassing the middle ear - This is the correct answer. Bone-anchored hearing aids work by transmitting sound vibrations directly through the skull bones to the inner ear, bypassing the middle ear. This is especially advantageous for patients with conductive hearing loss or chronic ear infections that affect the middle ear.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Amplification of high-frequency sounds - While BAHA devices can amplify sounds, their primary advantage is not specific to high-frequency sounds but rather their ability to bypass the middle ear entirely and provide better overall hearing in patients with conductive hearing loss.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bone-anchored hearing aids (BAHA) provide direct bone conduction of sound, bypassing the middle ear, making them particularly advantageous for patients with conductive hearing loss or chronic ear infections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and a history of recurrent sinus infections. Nasal endoscopy reveals a polypoid mass in the nasal cavity. Biopsy of the mass shows characteristic features of an inverted papilloma. Which of the following is a significant risk associated with inverted papilloma?

options.label: C
options.text: Tendency to cause nasal septal perforation

questions.correct_answer: B. Association with squamous cell carcinoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Association with squamous cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. High risk of metastasis - Inverted papillomas are benign tumors and do not metastasize. However, they have a locally aggressive nature and a high recurrence rate, but metastasis is not a concern.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Association with squamous cell carcinoma - This is the correct answer. Inverted papillomas have a significant risk of malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma. This association necessitates careful monitoring and complete surgical excision to reduce the risk of recurrence and malignant transformation.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Tendency to cause nasal septal perforation - While inverted papillomas can cause significant local destruction and remodeling, they do not typically cause nasal septal perforation. This complication is more common with other conditions like chronic nasal drug use or granulomatous diseases.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Commonly associated with allergic rhinitis - There is no strong association between inverted papilloma and allergic rhinitis. Inverted papillomas are typically related to other risk factors, such as human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, and not directly to allergic conditions.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inverted papillomas have a significant risk of malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma, necessitating careful monitoring and complete surgical excision to reduce the risk of recurrence and malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a sensation of something stuck in her throat and difficulty swallowing. Examination reveals normal vocal cord function but significant discomfort upon palpation of the area above the vocal cords. Which nerve provides the sensory supply to the larynx above the level of the vocal cords?

options.label: C
options.text: Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve

options.label: D
options.text: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerv

questions.correct_answer: C. Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Vagus nerve - The vagus nerve is the main nerve that innervates the larynx through its branches. However, it is not the specific nerve responsible for the sensory supply above the vocal cords.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Recurrent laryngeal nerve - The recurrent laryngeal nerve provides motor innervation to most of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx and sensory innervation below the level of the vocal cords, not above.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve - This is the correct answer. The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the mucosa of the larynx above the level of the vocal cords, making it responsible for the sensation in this area.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve - The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve innervates the cricothyroid muscle and is involved in motor function, not sensory supply above the vocal cords.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the larynx above the level of the vocal cords.

questions.text: An audiogram of a 30-year-old female patient is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Otosclerosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Otosclerosis - Otosclerosis typically presents with conductive hearing loss, which is characterized by a specific audiogram pattern. The audiogram shows an air-bone gap (difference between air conduction and bone conduction thresholds) with bone conduction being relatively preserved and air conduction being impaired. The pattern in the provided audiogram, showing progressively worsening hearing loss across frequencies with a notable gap between air and bone conduction, is consistent with otosclerosis.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Meniere’s disease - Meniere’s disease typically presents with fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, often more pronounced at lower frequencies, along with episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, and aural fullness. The audiogram usually shows a low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, which is not consistent with the pattern seen in this audiogram.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Noise-induced hearing loss - Noise-induced hearing loss is typically characterized by a "noise notch" at around 4000 Hz, where there is a dip in hearing sensitivity. The provided audiogram shows a gradual worsening of hearing across all frequencies, which is not typical for noise-induced hearing loss.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Presbycusis - Presbycusis, or age-related hearing loss, usually presents with a gradual high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. This condition is more common in older adults and presents with a different pattern on the audiogram, typically showing a slope at the high frequencies. The patient’s age and audiogram pattern do not match this diagnosis.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otosclerosis presents with a conductive hearing loss pattern on the audiogram, characterized by an air-bone gap with relatively preserved bone conduction and impaired air conduction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female singer presents with hoarseness and vocal fatigue that has been worsening over the past six months. She denies any smoking history or recent upper respiratory infections. Laryngoscopy reveals bilateral symmetrical lesions on the vocal cords as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vocal cord nodule

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Vocal cord polyp - Vocal cord polyps are typically unilateral and can vary in size and appearance. They often result from acute vocal trauma or irritation and do not usually present as bilateral symmetrical lesions.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Laryngeal papilloma - Laryngeal papillomas are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) and appear as multiple, small, wart-like growths rather than bilateral symmetrical lesions. They are less common in adults without a history of HPV infection.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Vocal cord nodule - This is the correct answer. Vocal cord nodules, also known as "singer's nodules" or "teacher's nodules," are benign, bilateral, symmetrical lesions that occur at the junction of the anterior and middle thirds of the vocal cords. They result from chronic vocal strain and are common in individuals who use their voice extensively, such as singers and teachers.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Laryngeal carcinoma - Laryngeal carcinoma typically presents as an irregular, unilateral mass with potential ulceration and is often associated with risk factors such as smoking and alcohol use. The symmetrical nature of the lesions in the image is not consistent with laryngeal carcinoma.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vocal cord nodules are bilateral, symmetrical lesions on the vocal cords commonly seen in individuals with chronic vocal strain, such as singers and teachers.

questions.text: A 40-year-old factory worker presents with difficulty hearing, particularly in noisy environments, and tinnitus. He has been working in a noisy environment for the past 15 years. Audiometry reveals a characteristic "noise notch" at 4000 Hz. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Noise-induced hearing loss

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Presbycusis - Presbycusis is age-related hearing loss, typically affecting high frequencies and occurring gradually in older adults. It does not present with a specific "noise notch" at 4000 Hz.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Otosclerosis - Otosclerosis involves abnormal bone growth in the middle ear leading to conductive hearing loss. It typically affects lower frequencies first and does not present with a "noise notch" at 4000 Hz.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Noise-induced hearing loss - This is the correct answer. Noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) is characterized by a specific audiometric finding known as the "noise notch" at around 4000 Hz. This pattern is indicative of damage to the hair cells in the cochlea due to prolonged exposure to loud noise.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Meniere’s disease - Meniere’s disease is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss (often affecting lower frequencies initially), tinnitus, and aural fullness. It does not typically present with a "noise notch" at 4000 Hz.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) is characterized by a "noise notch" at 4000 Hz on audiometry, indicating damage to cochlear hair cells from prolonged exposure to loud noise.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with sneezing, nasal congestion, itchy eyes, and clear rhinorrhea, especially in the spring and fall. She has no history of recent upper respiratory infections. Physical examination reveals pale, boggy nasal mucosa and bilateral infraorbital darkening. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Allergic rhinitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute bacterial sinusitis - Acute bacterial sinusitis typically presents with purulent nasal discharge, facial pain/pressure, and symptoms lasting more than 10 days or worsening after initial improvement. The patient’s symptoms of sneezing, itchy eyes, and clear rhinorrhea, along with the seasonal pattern, are not consistent with acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Vasomotor rhinitis - Vasomotor rhinitis presents with nasal congestion and rhinorrhea triggered by non-allergic stimuli such as changes in weather, strong odors, or smoke. It lacks the itchy eyes, sneezing, and seasonal pattern seen in allergic rhinitis.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Allergic rhinitis - This is the correct answer. Allergic rhinitis is characterized by sneezing, nasal congestion, itchy eyes, and clear rhinorrhea, often with a seasonal pattern. Physical examination findings of pale, boggy nasal mucosa and infraorbital darkening (allergic shiners) support this diagnosis.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Chronic rhinosinusitis - Chronic rhinosinusitis involves nasal congestion, facial pain/pressure, and nasal discharge lasting for more than 12 weeks. It typically includes symptoms like anosmia and does not have the pronounced seasonal pattern or allergic symptoms (itchy eyes, sneezing) seen in allergic rhinitis.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allergic rhinitis presents with sneezing, nasal congestion, itchy eyes, and clear rhinorrhea, often with a seasonal pattern, and physical examination may reveal pale, boggy nasal mucosa and infraorbital darkening (allergic shiners).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with itching, fullness, and mild discomfort in her right ear. She reports a history of recent swimming and frequent use of earplugs. Otoscopic examination reveals black debris and hyphae in the ear canal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Otomycosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute otitis externa - Acute otitis externa, also known as "swimmer’s ear," typically presents with ear pain, pruritus, and discharge. Otoscopic findings often show edema and erythema of the ear canal, but not the characteristic black debris and hyphae seen in fungal infections.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Otomycosis - This is the correct answer. Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the ear canal. It is characterized by symptoms such as itching, fullness, and mild discomfort. The presence of black debris and hyphae on otoscopic examination is typical for fungal pathogens, such as Aspergillus or Candida species.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Chronic suppurative otitis media - Chronic suppurative otitis media involves persistent ear discharge (otorrhea) through a perforated tympanic membrane. It does not typically present with the black debris and hyphae characteristic of otomycosis.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Cholesteatoma - Cholesteatoma presents with chronic ear discharge and hearing loss, and on examination, it reveals a white mass behind an intact or perforated tympanic membrane. It does not show the black debris and hyphae seen in otomycosis.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the ear canal, characterized by symptoms such as itching, fullness, and mild discomfort, with otoscopic examination revealing black debris and hyphae.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent ear discharge and hearing loss in the right ear for the past several months. He denies any recent ear pain or fever. Otoscopic examination reveals a retracted tympanic membrane with a marginal perforation in the attic region and cholesteatoma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Atticoantral chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Atticoantral chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute otitis media - Acute otitis media typically presents with ear pain, fever, and a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane. It is an acute condition and does not present with a retracted tympanic membrane or cholesteatoma.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Serous otitis media - Serous otitis media, also known as otitis media with effusion, involves the presence of non-infected fluid in the middle ear, typically causing a conductive hearing loss. The tympanic membrane is usually intact and not retracted or perforated.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Atticoantral chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) - This is the correct answer. Atticoantral CSOM is characterized by chronic ear discharge, hearing loss, a retracted tympanic membrane, marginal perforation, and the presence of cholesteatoma. It commonly involves the attic (pars flaccida) and the antrum of the mastoid bone, hence the name.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Tubotympanic chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) - Tubotympanic CSOM typically involves the central part of the tympanic membrane (pars tensa) and presents with central perforation and mucopurulent discharge. It does not usually involve cholesteatoma or marginal perforations in the attic region.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atticoantral chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is characterized by chronic ear discharge, hearing loss, a retracted tympanic membrane, marginal perforation, and the presence of cholesteatoma.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with a history of multiple fractures with minimal trauma, blue sclerae, and hearing loss. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the COL1A1 gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Osteogenesis imperfecta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Osteogenesis imperfecta - This is the correct answer. Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI), also known as Van der Hoeve syndrome, is a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones leading to frequent fractures, blue sclerae, and hearing loss due to ossicular abnormalities. It is commonly caused by mutations in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 genes, which encode type I collagen.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome - Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a group of connective tissue disorders characterized by hypermobile joints, skin hyperextensibility, and tissue fragility. It does not typically present with multiple fractures, blue sclerae, or hearing loss.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Marfan syndrome - Marfan syndrome is a connective tissue disorder characterized by tall stature, long limbs, arachnodactyly, lens dislocation, and aortic aneurysms. It does not present with frequent fractures, blue sclerae, or hearing loss.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Achondroplasia - Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder characterized by short stature, disproportionately short limbs, and macrocephaly. It is not associated with multiple fractures, blue sclerae, or hearing loss.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteogenesis imperfecta, also known as Van der Hoeve syndrome, is a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones leading to frequent fractures, blue sclerae, and hearing loss due to ossicular abnormalities.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with ear pain, fever, and irritability. His mother reports that he had a recent upper respiratory infection. Otoscopic examination reveals a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with decreased mobility. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Serous otitis media - Serous otitis media, also known as otitis media with effusion, typically presents with non-infected fluid in the middle ear and does not cause acute pain, fever, or a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane. It usually follows an episode of acute otitis media.
  • • Option A.
