  • • Option B. Chronic suppurative otitis media - Chronic suppurative otitis media involves persistent ear discharge (otorrhea) through a perforated tympanic membrane for more than six weeks. It is usually not associated with acute pain and fever.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) - This is the correct answer. ASOM presents with ear pain, fever, and irritability, often following an upper respiratory infection. The otoscopic findings of a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with decreased mobility are characteristic of ASOM.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Otomycosis - Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the external ear canal and presents with itching, fullness, and sometimes mild discomfort, along with characteristic findings of fungal debris. It does not cause a bulging tympanic membrane or acute systemic symptoms like fever.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) presents with ear pain, fever, and a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with decreased mobility, often following an upper respiratory infection.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with chronic nasal congestion, facial pain, and recurrent sinus infections. A CT scan of the paranasal sinuses reveals the presence of an air cell (indicated by the red arrow) extending into the floor of the orbit. What is the anatomical structure most likely being identified by the red arrow?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Haller cell

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Agger nasi cell - The agger nasi cell is the most anterior ethmoidal air cell and is located near the frontal recess. It is not located at the floor of the orbit and does not cause the symptoms presented in this case.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Onodi cell - The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that extends superolaterally to the sphenoid sinus and can be close to the optic nerve. It is not located near the floor of the orbit.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Haller cell - This is the correct answer. Haller cells are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit. They can impinge on the maxillary sinus ostium, leading to chronic nasal congestion, facial pain, and recurrent sinus infections.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Concha bullosa - Concha bullosa refers to pneumatization of the middle turbinate. It is not located in the floor of the orbit and does not directly cause the symptoms presented in this case.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Haller cells, or infraorbital ethmoidal air cells, extend into the floor of the orbit and can lead to chronic nasal congestion, facial pain, and recurrent sinus infections by impinging on the maxillary sinus ostium.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to hearing loss in his right ear. There is no history of ear infections or trauma. Otoscopic examination reveals a pearly white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Congenital cholesteatoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute otitis media - Acute otitis media typically presents with ear pain, fever, and a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane. It does not present with a pearly white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Congenital cholesteatoma - This is the correct answer. Congenital cholesteatoma is characterized by a pearly white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane. It occurs due to the presence of keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear from birth, and often presents with hearing loss without a history of ear infections or trauma.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Serous otitis media - Serous otitis media involves the presence of non-infected fluid in the middle ear, which can cause hearing loss. The tympanic membrane typically appears dull and may show an air-fluid level, but it does not present with a pearly white mass.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Otosclerosis - Otosclerosis is a condition characterized by abnormal bone growth in the middle ear, leading to conductive hearing loss. It does not present with a visible mass behind the tympanic membrane.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital cholesteatoma presents as a pearly white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane and typically causes hearing loss without a history of ear infections or trauma.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient presents to the ENT clinic with complaints of hearing trouble in his left ear for the past two months. The doctor performs pure tone audiometry, as shown below. What is the interpretation of the audiogram?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Left-sided conductive deafness

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Left-sided conductive deafness - This is the correct answer. The audiogram shows a significant air-bone gap on the left side, where air conduction thresholds are elevated while bone conduction thresholds remain within normal limits. This pattern is characteristic of conductive hearing loss, where there is a problem with sound transmission through the outer or middle ear.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Left-sided sensorineural deafness - Sensorineural hearing loss would show elevated thresholds for both air and bone conduction with no air-bone gap. This pattern is not observed in the provided audiogram.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Right-sided conductive deafness - The right side of the audiogram shows normal hearing thresholds for both air and bone conduction, indicating no hearing loss on the right side.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Right-sided sensorineural deafness - The right side of the audiogram shows normal hearing thresholds for both air and bone conduction, indicating no hearing loss on the right side.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conductive hearing loss is indicated by an air-bone gap on the audiogram, where air conduction thresholds are elevated while bone conduction thresholds remain normal.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being struck in the nose during a basketball game. He complains of nasal pain and difficulty breathing through his nose. On examination, his nasal septum appears swollen and fluctuant to touch. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Septal hematoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Nasal fracture - While nasal fractures can occur with trauma to the nose and can cause pain and swelling, the key feature of a septal hematoma is the fluctuant swelling of the nasal septum. Nasal fractures typically present with deformity, tenderness, and crepitus but not fluctuant swelling.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Septal hematoma - This is the correct answer. A septal hematoma is characterized by a collection of blood between the septal cartilage and its overlying perichondrium. This results in a swollen, fluctuant septum and can lead to complications if not promptly treated.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Deviated septum - A deviated septum is a structural condition where the nasal septum is displaced to one side. It can cause chronic nasal obstruction but typically does not present acutely with fluctuant swelling.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Nasal polyps - Nasal polyps are non-cancerous growths within the nasal cavity or sinuses, often associated with chronic inflammation. They do not appear suddenly after trauma and do not present as fluctuant swelling of the nasal septum.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A septal hematoma is characterized by a swollen, fluctuant nasal septum following trauma and requires prompt treatment to prevent complications such as septal abscess or cartilage necrosis.

questions.text: A newborn presents with cyanosis that improves when crying and worsens when feeding. On physical examination, there is no airflow through the nostrils. A catheter cannot be passed through the nasal passage into the oropharynx. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Choanal atresia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Nasal polyps - Nasal polyps are non-cancerous growths within the nasal passage that typically present in older children or adults with chronic rhinosinusitis or allergic conditions. They do not present with the classic signs of neonatal cyanosis that improves with crying.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Choanal atresia - This is the correct answer. Choanal atresia is a congenital condition where the back of the nasal passage is blocked, usually by bone or soft tissue. This condition leads to difficulty breathing, especially when feeding, as neonates are obligate nasal breathers. The classic sign of cyanosis that improves with crying is a key diagnostic feature.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Foreign body obstruction - Foreign body obstruction can cause acute respiratory distress and nasal blockage but is less likely in a newborn. The presentation in a newborn with cyanosis relieved by crying strongly suggests a congenital condition like choanal atresia.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Deviated septum - A deviated septum can cause nasal obstruction but is not typically associated with cyanosis that improves with crying in a newborn. It is usually identified later in life and not a cause of neonatal respiratory distress.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Choanal atresia is a congenital condition characterized by blockage of the nasal passages, leading to respiratory distress in newborns, with cyanosis that improves when crying due to the obligate nasal breathing pattern of infants.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of fever, drooling, difficulty swallowing, and a muffled "hot potato" voice. He is sitting forward in the "tripod" position to help with breathing. On examination, his epiglottis appears swollen and cherry-red. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute epiglottitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Croup - Croup is characterized by a barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness, typically caused by a viral infection. It does not usually present with drooling or a muffled voice, and the "tripod" position is not characteristic of croup.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Acute epiglottitis - This is the correct answer. Acute epiglottitis is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by sudden onset of fever, drooling, difficulty swallowing, a muffled "hot potato" voice, and the "tripod" position. The cherry-red, swollen epiglottis is a key diagnostic feature.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Peritonsillar abscess - Peritonsillar abscess presents with fever, severe sore throat, muffled voice, and unilateral swelling of the tonsil with deviation of the uvula. It is less likely to cause drooling and the "tripod" position.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Retropharyngeal abscess - Retropharyngeal abscess can cause fever, neck pain, difficulty swallowing, and muffled voice, but it is more commonly associated with neck stiffness and swelling rather than the "tripod" position and cherry-red epiglottis.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute epiglottitis is characterized by sudden onset of fever, drooling, difficulty swallowing, a muffled "hot potato" voice, and the "tripod" position, with a swollen and cherry-red epiglottis being a key diagnostic feature.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with a history of nasal obstruction for the last 2 months. A CT scan was done, and the following findings are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Antrochoanal polyp

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Adenoid hypertrophy - Adenoid hypertrophy typically occurs in younger children and presents with nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and snoring. On CT scan, it appears as soft tissue mass in the nasopharynx, not as a large mass filling the nasal cavity and extending into the nasopharynx as seen in the image.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma - This benign vascular tumor occurs almost exclusively in adolescent males and presents with recurrent epistaxis and nasal obstruction. It typically shows an enhancing mass on CT with bone erosion, which does not match the findings in the image.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma - Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor that can present with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and neck masses due to lymphadenopathy. It usually shows an irregular mass in the nasopharynx with possible bone destruction, which is not the presentation in the CT image.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Antrochoanal polyp - This is the correct answer. Antrochoanal polyps are benign, unilateral polyps that originate in the maxillary sinus and extend into the nasal cavity and nasopharynx. They present with nasal obstruction and are well-demarcated on CT, which matches the findings seen in the image.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Antrochoanal polyps are benign, unilateral polyps that originate in the maxillary sinus and extend into the nasal cavity and nasopharynx, presenting with nasal obstruction and characteristic CT findings.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with chronic nasal obstruction, crusting, and occasional epistaxis. She has a history of progressive nasal and facial deformity over the past several years. Biopsy of the nasal tissue reveals granulomatous inflammation with Mikulicz cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rhinoscleroma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Wegener's granulomatosis - Also known as granulomatosis with polyangiitis, this condition is characterized by necrotizing granulomatous inflammation and vasculitis affecting the upper and lower respiratory tracts and kidneys. It typically does not present with Mikulicz cells.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Rhinoscleroma - This is the correct answer. Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It presents with chronic nasal obstruction, crusting, epistaxis, and progressive nasal and facial deformity. Biopsy reveals characteristic Mikulicz cells (large foamy macrophages).
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Sarcoidosis - Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease that can involve the upper respiratory tract but is more commonly associated with hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary involvement. It does not typically present with Mikulicz cells.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Leprosy - Caused by Mycobacterium leprae, leprosy affects the skin, peripheral nerves, and mucosa of the upper respiratory tract. It presents with characteristic skin lesions and sensory loss but does not involve Mikulicz cells or present with the chronic nasal symptoms described.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, presenting with chronic nasal obstruction, crusting, and progressive nasal and facial deformity, characterized by the presence of Mikulicz cells in the biopsy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with episodes of vertigo that are triggered by changes in head position, such as turning in bed or looking up. He experiences brief episodes of intense dizziness, often accompanied by nausea. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm a dysfunction in the semicircular canals?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dix-Hallpike maneuver

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pure tone audiometry - Pure tone audiometry is used to assess hearing thresholds and diagnose hearing loss. It does not evaluate vestibular function or semicircular canal dysfunction.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Dix-Hallpike maneuver - This is the correct answer. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is a positional test used to diagnose benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is caused by dysfunction in the semicircular canals, specifically the posterior canal. It involves rapidly moving the patient from a sitting to a lying position with the head turned, observing for nystagmus and vertigo.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Rinne and Weber tests - These tests are used to differentiate between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss. They do not assess vestibular function or semicircular canal dysfunction.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Tympanometry - Tympanometry is used to evaluate middle ear function by measuring the mobility of the tympanic membrane in response to changes in air pressure. It does not assess vestibular function or semicircular canal dysfunction.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is a clinical test used to diagnose benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is caused by dysfunction in the semicircular canals and presents with episodes of vertigo triggered by changes in head position.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, and a reddish-blue mass visible behind the tympanic membrane on otoscopic examination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glomus tumor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acoustic neuroma - Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, typically presents with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, but it does not usually cause a visible mass behind the tympanic membrane.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Cholesteatoma - Cholesteatoma is a benign growth of keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear and mastoid. It often presents with hearing loss and otorrhea, but not with a pulsatile tinnitus or a reddish-blue mass behind the tympanic membrane.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Glomus tumor - This is the correct answer. Glomus tumors (also known as paragangliomas) are highly vascular tumors that can present with pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss, and a reddish-blue mass visible behind the tympanic membrane. They are the most common benign tumors of the middle ear.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Meniere’s disease - Meniere’s disease is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. It does not present with a visible mass behind the tympanic membrane.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glomus tumors are highly vascular tumors of the middle ear that present with pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss, and a reddish-blue mass visible behind the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with persistent tearing and recurrent eye infections. Examination reveals swelling over the medial canthus of her left eye. Which part of the lacrimal system is most likely obstructed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nasolacrimal duct

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Lacrimal gland - The lacrimal gland produces tears and is located in the upper outer part of the orbit. Obstruction here would not cause swelling over the medial canthus or recurrent infections related to tear drainage.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Lacrimal puncta - The lacrimal puncta are small openings at the medial canthus that allow tears to drain from the eye's surface into the canaliculi. While obstruction here can cause tearing, it would not typically cause significant swelling over the medial canthus.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Nasolacrimal duct - This is the correct answer. The nasolacrimal duct drains tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity. Obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct can lead to dacryocystitis, which presents with tearing, swelling, and infection over the medial canthus.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Lacrimal canaliculi - The lacrimal canaliculi are small channels that drain tears from the puncta to the lacrimal sac. Obstruction here can cause tearing, but significant swelling over the medial canthus is more commonly associated with nasolacrimal duct obstruction.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct can lead to dacryocystitis, presenting with tearing, swelling, and infection over the medial canthus of the eye.
